posts.title: AI Overviews SEO: How to Get Cited (2026)
posts.description: A practical checklist to increase your odds of being cited in Google AI Overviews.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

To get cited in AI Overviews, you need **clear answers**, **evidence**, and **trust signals**. Write content that is easy for machines to parse and strong enough for humans to trust.

## Why AI Overviews reduce clicks

AI Overviews often satisfy the query on Google. That means fewer clicks—unless your page is **cited** or the query is **complex**.

## The citation checklist

### 1) Put the answer first

Start with a 2–4 sentence answer. Then expand.

### 2) Use scannable structure

- Short paragraphs
- Lists
- Tables for comparisons
- Consistent headings (H2/H3)

### 3) Add “anti‑AI” signals

AI can summarize, but it can’t *experience*. Add:

- first‑hand notes
- screenshots
- original examples
- real numbers (even small experiments)

### 4) Build internal topical support

Create supporting pages and link them together.

### 5) Strengthen E‑E‑A‑T

- Author bio
- Editorial policy
- Update timestamps
- Clear sources for claims

posts.title: Canonical Tags: When to Use Them (and When Not To)
posts.description: How canonical tags prevent duplicate indexing and consolidate ranking signals.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Use canonicals when multiple URLs show the same content and you want one primary URL indexed.

## Common cases

- UTM parameters
- sorting/filter pages
- near-duplicate pages

## Related

If you have lots of duplicates, consider: [Content pruning](/blog/seo-content-pruning).

posts.title: Content Brief Template: Write Faster, Rank Faster
posts.description: A simple content brief format: intent, outline, SERP notes, and internal links.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

A content brief prevents thin content and makes internal linking automatic.

## Template

- Primary keyword + intent
- The “answer first” paragraph
- H2/H3 outline
- 5 internal links to include (see: [Topical authority](/blog/internal-linking-topical-authority))
- FAQ questions

## Related

Use this when scaling: [Programmatic SEO starter](/blog/programmatic-seo-starter).

posts.title: Content Refresh Playbook: Update Old Posts to Rank
posts.description: How to refresh existing content for better rankings and AI citations.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Refreshing content often beats publishing new posts because you keep the existing URL history.

## The playbook

1) Update the first 200 words (answer-first)
2) Add 3–5 new internal links to related pages
3) Improve headings (H2/H3) and add an FAQ
4) Add examples or small tests (experience)

## Internal linking rule

Every refresh should strengthen the cluster. Use this guide: [Topical authority & internal linking](/blog/internal-linking-topical-authority).

posts.title: Silos vs Clusters: The Modern Content Structure
posts.description: Why topical clusters beat rigid silos for rankings and AI understanding.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Clusters are flexible and map better to how Google understands topics.

## Practical model

- Pillar page
- Supporting pages
- Contextual internal links both directions

## Start here

Read: [Topical authority](/blog/internal-linking-topical-authority).

posts.title: Core Web Vitals Mini Guide: Fix LCP, INP, CLS
posts.description: A short guide to the 3 metrics that usually matter most for UX and rankings.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Most sites improve CWV by fixing images, scripts, and layout shifts.

## Quick fixes

- LCP: compress hero image, reduce render-blocking scripts
- INP: remove heavy JS, defer third-party scripts
- CLS: set image/video dimensions and avoid late-loading banners

## Related

Start with the full checklist: [Technical SEO checklist](/blog/technical-seo-checklist).

posts.title: E‑E‑A‑T Checklist (2026): Prove Trust Fast
posts.description: A simple E‑E‑A‑T checklist you can apply to every important page.
posts.content:
## What E‑E‑A‑T is

E‑E‑A‑T stands for **Experience, Expertise, Authoritativeness, Trust**. In 2026 it’s how you separate real sites from mass AI content.

## The checklist

### Page-level

- A clear author (real person) with bio
- Evidence of experience (photos, steps, screenshots, “we tested…")
- References when facts matter
- Updated date when content changes

### Site-level

- About page with who/why
- Contact page
- Editorial policy
- Privacy policy

### Content-level

- No thin pages
- No duplicated pages
- Strong internal linking to supporting guides

## Quick win

Pick your top 10 pages and apply the checklist. Then prune or merge the weakest pages.

posts.title: Google Business Profile Optimization: Quick Checklist
posts.description: GBP fields and habits that improve visibility in the map pack.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Most local wins come from complete profiles + consistent activity.

## Checklist

- Correct primary category
- Services filled out
- Real photos weekly
- Answer Q&A
- Respond to reviews

## Foundation

Start here: [Local SEO foundations](/blog/local-seo-foundations).

posts.title: Topical Authority: Internal Linking That Actually Works
posts.description: How to build clusters and internal links that help rankings and AI citations.
posts.content:
## The principle

Google understands topics through **relationships**. Internal links are how you declare those relationships.

## A simple cluster model

- 1 pillar page (broad)
- 5–15 supporting pages (specific)
- 2–5 links per page to related pages

## Link rules

- Link when it helps the reader (contextual)
- Use descriptive anchor text (not “click here”)
- Keep your important pages within 2–3 clicks from home

## Maintenance

Every time you publish a new article:

1) add 3–5 internal links from older posts → the new post
2) add 3–5 links from the new post → older supporting posts

posts.title: Keyword Research (Modern): Intent > Volume
posts.description: How to pick keywords using intent, SERP layouts, and AI Overviews behavior.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

In 2026, a keyword is not just volume — it’s **intent + SERP features + AI answers**.

## The method

- Group keywords by intent (informational / commercial / transactional)
- Check if AI Overviews appear (see: [AI Overviews SEO](/blog/ai-overviews-seo))
- Target complex queries where AI can’t fully answer

## Close the loop

Once you publish, connect it into your cluster: [Internal linking](/blog/internal-linking-topical-authority).

posts.title: Link Building in 2026: Digital PR Basics
posts.description: A simple digital PR approach: data, angles, and outreach that earns real links.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Stop chasing spam links. Earn links by publishing something journalists can cite.

## The approach

- Create a small dataset (even 50–200 samples)
- Publish the insight + charts
- Pitch the angle to writers in your niche

## Strengthen trust

Links work best with trust pages: [Editorial policy](/editorial-policy) + [E‑E‑A‑T checklist](/blog/eeat-checklist).

posts.title: Local SEO Foundations (2026): What Actually Matters
posts.description: The core local SEO signals that move the needle: GBP, NAP, reviews, and location pages.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Local SEO is trust + proximity + relevance. You win by being the most credible local option.

## The foundations

- Google Business Profile: categories, services, photos
- NAP consistency (name/address/phone)
- Review velocity + response rate
- Location/service pages that match real queries

## Tie-in with E‑E‑A‑T

Local trust is E‑E‑A‑T in practice. Start here: [E‑E‑A‑T checklist](/blog/eeat-checklist).

posts.title: Location Pages Best Practices (for Local + Programmatic SEO)
posts.description: How to build city pages that are unique, helpful, and not duplicate content.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Location pages work when each page contains local proof, unique details, and clear services.

## What to include

- Services offered in that location
- Local FAQs
- Testimonials/case studies
- Internal links to the main service pillar

## Avoid duplication

Use canonicals carefully: [Canonical tags](/blog/canonical-tags).

posts.title: On-Page SEO Quick Guide: Titles, Headings, and UX
posts.description: A simple on-page SEO guide for titles, headings, and user experience.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

On-page SEO is about clarity: the page should be instantly understandable to humans and machines.

## Quick checklist

- One clear H1
- Descriptive H2/H3 structure
- Short answer at the top
- Internal links to supporting pages

## Next

If you want stronger site-wide results, apply: [Content refresh playbook](/blog/content-refresh-playbook).

posts.title: Programmatic SEO Starter: 5 Page Types That Scale
posts.description: A beginner-friendly programmatic SEO plan using scalable page templates.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Programmatic SEO works when each template page is genuinely useful and not duplicate.

## 5 templates that work

1) Location pages (City + service)
2) Comparison pages (X vs Y)
3) Alternatives pages
4) Use-case pages
5) Glossary pages

## Avoid the biggest mistake

Thin/duplicated pages hurt site quality. Use: [Technical SEO checklist](/blog/technical-seo-checklist).

posts.title: Reviews for Local SEO: How to Get More (Without Spam)
posts.description: Simple review acquisition systems and how to respond for trust.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

You need consistent review velocity, not one big spike.

## Simple system

- Ask at the right moment (after value delivered)
- Use a short link/QR
- Reply to every review

## Related

Trust system-wide matters: [E‑E‑A‑T checklist](/blog/eeat-checklist).

posts.title: Schema Markup Basics: What to Implement First
posts.description: The highest-impact schema types for most sites: Organization, Article, FAQ, Breadcrumbs.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Start with schema that improves understanding, not gimmicks: **Organization**, **Breadcrumb**, and **Article**. Add **FAQ** when it genuinely helps.

## What to implement first

1) Organization / Website
2) BreadcrumbList
3) Article (or BlogPosting)
4) FAQPage (only for real FAQs)

## Pair it with structure

Schema works best when your content is well structured: [On-page SEO quick guide](/blog/on-page-seo-quick).

posts.title: Content Pruning: Delete Pages to Improve SEO
posts.description: When deleting or merging pages is the fastest way to improve site quality.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

If you have lots of thin pages, your good pages suffer. Pruning can raise overall quality signals.

## What to prune

- Pages with no traffic and no purpose
- Duplicate topics
- Outdated pages that can be merged

## Pruning process

1) Export URLs and traffic
2) Decide: keep / merge / redirect / delete
3) Update internal links (see: [Internal linking](/blog/internal-linking-topical-authority))

## Related

Trust signals matter more after pruning: [E‑E‑A‑T checklist](/blog/eeat-checklist).

posts.title: SEO Content Templates: 5 Formats That Rank
posts.description: The five post formats that consistently perform: how-to, checklist, comparison, glossary, playbook.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Pick a format that matches intent. Don’t force every topic into a “how-to”.

## 5 templates

- How-to
- Checklist
- Comparison
- Glossary
- Playbook
- (Bonus) Case study

## Related

Start from intent: [Keyword research (modern)](/blog/keyword-research-modern).

posts.title: SEO FAQs: When They Help (and When They Hurt)
posts.description: How to add FAQs that improve clarity and AI citations without bloating content.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

FAQs help when they answer real questions and reduce confusion. They hurt when they’re filler.

## 3 rules

- Use questions from Search Console / support tickets
- Keep answers short and specific
- Link to deeper guides where needed

## Related

Write answers-first sections: [AI search answer blocks](/blog/seo-for-ai-search-snippets).

posts.title: SEO for AI Search: Answer Blocks That Get Cited
posts.description: How to write answer blocks and evidence sections that AI systems like to cite.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

To be cited, make it easy to extract: **short answer**, **bullets**, then **proof**.

## The block pattern

- 2–4 sentence direct answer
- Bullets (steps, options, definitions)
- Evidence section (sources, screenshots, examples)

## Related

Start with the bigger picture: [AI Overviews SEO](/blog/ai-overviews-seo).

posts.title: Glossary SEO Strategy: Build Topical Coverage
posts.description: How glossary pages build internal linking and long-tail traffic.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Glossary pages are easy to maintain and great for internal linking.

## How to do it

- Keep definitions short
- Add examples
- Link to 2–3 related guides

## Related

Clusters win: [Topical authority](/blog/internal-linking-topical-authority).

posts.title: SEO Landing Pages: Rank + Convert
posts.description: How to create landing pages that rank and convert without keyword stuffing.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Good SEO landing pages match intent, build trust, and make the next step obvious.

## What to include

- Clear value proposition
- Proof (cases, testimonials, data)
- FAQ section
- Internal links to relevant guides

## Trust matters

Apply: [E‑E‑A‑T checklist](/blog/eeat-checklist).

posts.title: SEO Metrics That Matter (GA4): What to Track
posts.description: The simplest SEO measurement setup using GA4: what to track and why.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Track outcomes, not vanity metrics. Rankings alone don’t pay the bills.

## Metrics to track

- Organic sessions (trend)
- Conversions from organic
- Top landing pages
- Branded vs non‑branded queries (in Search Console)

## Also track AI impact

If AI Overviews reduce clicks, measure it per page: [AI Overviews SEO](/blog/ai-overviews-seo).

posts.title: SEO Migration Checklist: Don’t Lose Traffic
posts.description: A short migration checklist for redesigns, domain changes, and CMS moves.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Most migration losses come from broken redirects, missing pages, and noindex mistakes.

## Checklist

- Crawl old site and export URLs
- 1:1 redirect mapping (301)
- Keep the same content where possible
- Monitor Search Console after launch

## Related

Redirect rules: [301 vs 302](/blog/seo-redirects-101).

posts.title: 301 vs 302 Redirects: SEO Rules of Thumb
posts.description: Simple rules for redirects that protect rankings during migrations and pruning.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

- Use **301** when a move is permanent.
- Use **302** only for truly temporary changes.

## Migration basics

- Map old → new URLs
- Avoid redirect chains
- Update internal links (see: [Site architecture](/blog/seo-site-architecture))

posts.title: Site Architecture for SEO: 3-Click Rule + Clusters
posts.description: A simple model for site structure that improves crawlability and topical authority.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

The best architecture makes it easy to find important pages within 2–3 clicks.

## The model

- Home → Category → Article
- Pillar pages → supporting pages (cluster)

## What to do today

- Create categories (done)
- Add internal links in every post

Use this: [Topical authority guide](/blog/internal-linking-topical-authority).

posts.title: SEO Title Formulas That Still Work (2026)
posts.description: Reliable title patterns for clicks, clarity, and AI-friendly structure.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Great titles are clear, specific, and match intent. Use a few proven patterns and stop overthinking.

## 6 title patterns

- How to + outcome
- Checklist: X items
- The playbook for X
- X vs Y (comparison)
- Best X for Y (buyer intent)
- Mistakes to avoid

## Pair with on-page

Titles work best with strong headings: [On-page SEO quick guide](/blog/on-page-seo-quick).

posts.title: Topic Map: Plan Your SEO Content Like a System
posts.description: A simple way to map pillars, supporting articles, and internal links before writing.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

A topic map prevents random posting. It turns your site into a connected knowledge graph.

## Steps

1) Pick 5 core pillars
2) List 10–20 supporting topics each
3) Decide internal links upfront

## Start here

Use: [Content brief template](/blog/content-brief-template).

posts.title: Technical SEO Checklist (2026): Fast Wins
posts.description: A practical technical SEO checklist to improve crawlability, speed, and indexation.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Technical SEO is about making your site easy to **crawl**, **index**, and **render** — fast.

## Checklist (fast wins)

### Crawl & index

- Submit `sitemap.xml` and keep it updated
- Make sure important pages are not `noindex`
- Fix redirect chains
- Remove/merge thin pages (see: [E‑E‑A‑T checklist](/blog/eeat-checklist))

### Site architecture

- Keep important pages within 2–3 clicks
- Use internal linking clusters (see: [Topical authority](/blog/internal-linking-topical-authority))

### Speed (Core Web Vitals)

- Compress images
- Reduce heavy scripts
- Avoid layout shifts (CLS)

## What to do next

If your traffic is dropping, also check AI behavior: [AI Overviews SEO](/blog/ai-overviews-seo).

posts.title: Welcome to SEO & AI Academy
posts.description: What this site is, who it's for, and how to use it.
posts.content:
SEO is changing fast. This site explains **modern SEO** in the age of **AI Overviews / SGE**, zero‑click searches, and semantic search.

## What you'll find here

- Practical SEO guides (technical + content)
- AI search behavior (how engines summarize and cite sources)
- Playbooks, checklists, and templates

## Start here

1. Understand how AI search changes clicks
2. Learn E‑E‑A‑T and trust signals
3. Build topical clusters and internal linking

posts.title: Zero-Click SEO Strategy: How to Win Without the Click
posts.description: Tactics for visibility when Google answers queries directly: branding, snippets, and intent.
posts.content:
## The quick answer

Zero-click is not the enemy. You win by targeting queries that still need decisions and by earning citations.

## Practical tactics

- Target complex queries (comparison, opinion, decision)
- Build a brand that users search for again
- Use internal links to move readers to deeper pages

## Related

See: [Keyword research (modern)](/blog/keyword-research-modern) and [AI search answer blocks](/blog/seo-for-ai-search-snippets).
